Same as below.
Done

image.int() maybe?

or image.fd?

static cast is an odd choice here (I'm a little surprised it works).
Done
This copy looks unnecessary?
Its needed as looks like https://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man3/mkdtemp.3.html changes the last six characters XXXXXX of imageXXXXXX and generates a unique string.

This is going to be an expensive operation.  Given that this is a single thread reactor now, you probably want to do this on its own thread?  Or make a coroutine friendly version that does this incrementally?

As written, the daemon will not respond to dbus calls while it's untarring, which is bad, because it causes problems in the Redfish task service implementation.
The unTar does a fork internally since it calls popen. unTar is defined in software_utils.cpp.

As implemented, any return path you take above here now gets "stuck" in the updating state.  For something thats supposed to be highly reliable (like a firmware update) that's bad.

Is there a reason we're explicitly limiting ourselves to one update?  I don't see any shared resources here, so supporting multiple updates at a time seems like it keeps the code simpler, and reduces the chance we deadlock.
The shared resource is the BMC flash itself which shouldn't be updated at the same time.
This is a very large method, can it be broken down at all?

I looked into this. The function follows the logical flow of extracting different sections from the image which further gets used to create some objects at end, so doesn't seem like we can break this further.
In this implementation, does this matter?
Yes, it does, as we shouldn't be updating the BMC flash in parallel.
Using namespace is called out in cppcoreguidelines as something not to do.
Done

I'd like to see startUpdate() handle the requested ApplyTime, that's why it was added as a parameter to the method. There's a suggestion on patch 70665 to signal the activation to bypass the checkApplyTimeImmediate() call if it's the new API, so now it's up to this new API to handle (via a new method?) the request ApplyTime value without needing it to save it in a unique_ptr and relying on the old code to do handle it. The old checkApplyTimeImmediate() will be deprecated eventually anyways because we want to handle more than 2 ApplyTime values eventually.

I don't think we can make the decision where to reboot the BMC or not as part of startUpdate. The reason for that is the update happens in an async fashion and the final action needs to be taken at Activation::onFlashWriteSuccess(), thats where the checkApplyTimeImmediate() is being called right now. So, i don't think we can change all that flow.
But, we can definitely use it inside StartUpdate for future usecases like stage and activate later kind of flow. Thats why i kept it inside the check for Immediate or onReset at the moment.
You're right, I've added a comment to 70665 to pass the value from Start Update when we create the Activation object.
Done
requestActivation() returns a bool but the return value is not checked here?
Acknowledged
